Description: Scarab in dark blue glass, slightly iridescent; naturalistic carving on one side; back with elytra and prothorax marked with a single deep line; underside not decorated; pierced lengthways; damaged surface.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Scarab Factory (according to the museum's register; unlikely)
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by City Art Gallery and Museum, Bristol. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

The material is rather rare in scarabs’ production. A scarab made in blue glass, with an inscription preserved on its underside, was discovered in the Third Intermediate Period cemetery at Matmar (Brunton, G. 1948. Matmar, London, pl. LXIII, 92). The finds at Matmar are mainly dated to the 8th-7th c. BC. A second scarab in blue glass was uncovered in Naukratis: Cairo, Egyptian Museum TR14/9/18/19. The Scarab Factory is a dubious findspot. Griffith reported finding a very roughly moulded glass scarabaeus in the north-west corner of Great Temenos (Notebook 150, p. 11). Brunton, G. 1948. Matmar, London.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OK.252)
